SectionNotes: This chapter defines the controls and activities necessary to ensure that all purchased products and services conform to the Company’s specified requirements. It covers supplier evaluation, procurement ethics, hazardous material restrictions, and authorization procedures for shipboard purchasing.

Objectives: Ensure that all purchased products and services meet specified quality, safety, and environmental requirements.
Establish proper controls for supplier selection, evaluation, and approval.
Prevent unethical practices and conflicts of interest in the purchasing process.

Details: Purchasing is based on competitive bidding and negotiation to achieve the best value for the Company.
Suppliers must be approved and periodically evaluated to maintain their approved status.
Supplier evaluations consider quality, reliability, delivery performance, and HSQE compliance.
Information from supplier bids and offers is confidential and restricted to authorized personnel.

Topics.TopicTitle: Ethical Conduct and Conflicts of Interest
Details: Personnel must not accept or request gifts, favors, or personal benefits from suppliers or prospective suppliers.
Any situation that may be construed as a conflict of interest must be disclosed immediately to the Purchasing Manager or the Master.
Employees involved in purchasing must act with integrity and prioritize the Company’s best interests.
All equipment, spare parts, or replacement materials supplied for ships must be free of hazardous materials (refer to SMS Chapter 7.6).
Purchasing staff and suppliers must verify compliance before shipment or delivery.
Non-compliant items must not be accepted or installed onboard.
The Master is not authorized to make local purchases without prior approval from the Office.
Exceptions are allowed only in emergency situations and must be fully documented.
All shipboard purchasing must follow Company approval channels and recordkeeping requirements.

Questions.QuestionText: 1. What is the main purpose of the Purchasing and Supplier Control procedure?
Options: A. To simplify documentation of financial audits
B. To ensure purchased products and services meet Company specifications and requirements
C. To reduce the number of approved suppliers
D. To increase supplier competition only
Questions.Reason: The procedure ensures that all purchases conform to the Company’s technical, safety, and quality requirements.

Questions.QuestionText: 2. How does the Company select suppliers?
Options: A. Based on personal recommendations
B. Through competitive bidding and negotiation with approved suppliers
C. By automatic approval from the Master
D. By random assignment from a supplier list
Questions.Reason: Purchasing depends on competitive bidding and negotiation to ensure fair and value-driven supplier selection.

Questions.QuestionText: 3. What must be ensured regarding materials supplied for ships?
Options: A. They are locally manufactured
B. They are free of hazardous materials
C. They are purchased in bulk quantities only
D. They are compatible with older systems only
Questions.Reason: All items supplied must be free from hazardous materials in compliance with Company safety and environmental standards.

Questions.QuestionText: 4. What is the correct action if a crew member is offered a gift from a supplier?
Options: A. Accept it if the gift is small
B. Refuse and report the offer to the Purchasing Manager or Master
C. Accept it as a courtesy
D. Exchange it for a discount
Questions.Reason: Gifts or favors from suppliers must not be accepted; any such offer must be reported to prevent conflicts of interest.

Questions.QuestionText: 5. Who is authorized to make local purchases onboard?
Options: A. Any senior officer
B. The Master, but only with prior approval from the Office
C. The Chief Engineer without approval
D. The Ship’s Agent
Questions.Reason: The Master can only make local purchases with Office approval, except in emergencies where full documentation is required.

Questions.QuestionText: 6. Why is supplier evaluation performed periodically?
Options: A. To meet insurance company requirements
B. To confirm suppliers continue to meet Company performance and HSQE standards
C. To reduce paperwork
D. To renegotiate prices annually
Questions.Reason: Periodic evaluation ensures suppliers maintain compliance with Company performance, safety, and environmental standards.
